metadata.title: Osteoporosis
anatomical location body part affected: Musculoskeletal system; primarily bones of spinal vertebrae, pelvis, neck of femur, distal radius, and metacarpals; affects trabecular bone more than cortical bone
description: Osteoporosis (OP) is a skeletal disorder that causes bones to weaken and break. It is characterized by decreased bone mineral density (BMD) and weakened bony microvasculature, causing bone fragility(1,2,3,4)

Incidence/prevalence –It is estimated that by 2022, over 12 million persons older than 50 in the United States will have osteoporosis(5,6,7,8) –Approximately 200 million people worldwide are currently diagnosed with osteoporosis and it is more common in women than men. For postmenopausal women, osteoporosis is usually because of reduced estrogen levels.(5,6,8,9) –Over a million fractures in the United States are attributed to OP annually, and 70% are in women(5)

M80.M80.1: post oophorectomy osteoporosis with pathological fracture
M80.M80.2: osteoporosis of disuse with pathological fracture
M80.M80.3: postsurgical malabsorption osteoporosis with pathological fracture

M81.9.M82.8: osteoporosis in other diseases classified elsewhere

Optional.base: subclassification codes to indicate site of involvement for M80, M81, M82

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified

Presentation/signs and symptoms  (25,26,40) –Loss of height –Thoracic back pain –Thoracic and lumbar fractures –Pain –Stress fractures –Kyphosis(sometimes causing respiratory distress) –BMD T-score  ≤ –2.5 -A BMD T-score  compares a patient’s BMD to that of an established norm or standard. Generally, BMD test results are compared to the ideal BMD of a healthy 25–40-year-old  adult of the same sex. A T-score  of 0 means the BMD is equal to the norm for a healthy young adult. A T-score  between –1 and 1 is within 1 standard deviation (SD) of the ideal. A score between –1 and –2.5 SDs below that of the healthy young adult indicates low bone mass or osteopenia, and a score ≤ –2.5 SDs below the ideal indicates OP -A Z-score  is a comparison of the patient’s BMD with an age-matched  population -A Z-score  of < –2 should prompt an evaluation for causes of secondary OP Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
presentation signs and symptoms: –Loss of height –Thoracic back pain –Thoracic and lumbar fractures –Pain –Stress fractures –Kyphosis(sometimes causing respiratory distress) –BMD T-score  ≤ –2.5 -A BMD T-score  compares a patient’s BMD to that of an established norm or standard. Generally, BMD test results are compared to the ideal BMD of a healthy 25–40-year-old  adult of the same sex. A T-score  of 0 means the BMD is equal to the norm for a healthy young adult. A T-score  between –1 and 1 is within 1 standard deviation (SD) of the ideal. A score between –1 and –2.5 SDs below that of the healthy young adult indicates low bone mass or osteopenia, and a score ≤ –2.5 SDs below the ideal indicates OP -A Z-score  is a comparison of the patient’s BMD with an age-matched  population -A Z-score  of < –2 should prompt an evaluation for causes of secondary OP Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Stop the exam and notify physician if patient reports the onset of new musculoskeletal symptoms (e.g., pain, swelling, bruising, numbness, paralysis) or severe symptoms associated with exertion (e.g., chest pain, dyspnea, dizziness)
Patients with a history of recurrent falls should have a thorough assessment of fall risk.  (2) (See  Clinical Review ... Falls in Older Adults  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708541)
Assess fear of falling by direct questioning or use of Falls Efficacy Scale(7)

pathogenesis ,,,,: BMD declines continuously in women throughout adult life because bone formation, as a rule, fails to compensate for andoffset the normal bone loss with aging
OP results when peak bone mass (95% of peak reached by mid-teens)  is low in youth and/or bone resorption increasesmore than normal
Bone loading (i.e., weight-bearing  muscle contraction or exercise) is a major regulator of bone mass and bone geometry

The osteocyte network senses bone loading through the shearing stress of increased fluid flow in the lacunar-canal  system.The estrogen receptors in osteoblasts are then activated by several kinases and phosphorylation. In addition, extracellularmediators such as nitric oxide and prostaglandins may activate the osteoblasts
Unloading secondary to bed rest or physical inactivity results in rapid bone resorption and osteocyte apoptosis, leading todecreased capacity for bone formation

Proposed benefits of regular weight-bearing  physical activity or exercise program(5,6)–Exercising during growth phase of adolescence increases peak bone mass, thus providing a larger “bone bank” to drawfrom later in life–Regular weight-bearing  exercise throughout the lifespan helps to maintain BMD and bone geometry (studies show this istrue at least in the short term). Reduced weight-bearing exercises such as swimming or cycling seem to have less effect onBMD but may lower fracture risk indirectly by maintaining muscle mass and pulling force on bone–Practical weight-bearing  exercise that includes walking 30 to 60 minutes a day may preserve BMD–Muscle strengthening, flexibility, and balance training may reduce risk of falls and help prevent recurrent falls
risk factors: Nonmodifiable–Age-Predominantly affects those ≥ 65 years of age(17)–Sex-Female(17)-Postmenopausal women are at greatest risk(17)–Genetics-Family history of OP–Race-More common in persons of Caucasian and Asian descent(17)–Fracture history-History of an atraumatic fracture

Modifiable–Low body weight (< 58kg) or BMI < 21(17)–High level of endurance training that promotes exercise-related  amenorrhea in females–A diet low in calcium or vitamin D(17)–Lack of physical activity and weight-bearing exercise(17)–Tobacco use–Excessive alcohol intake (> 3 drinks/day)–Excessive caffeine intake–Suboptimal B-vitamin  status associated with high levels of serum total homocysteine and methylmalonic acid increasesrisk of lumbar OP in women(41)–Hyponatremia (low serum sodium, < 135 mmol/L) was associated with increased risk of total hip OP in a study with24,784 patients in the United States(42)–History of falls(1,2)

Medications–SSRIs(17)–Antiepileptics(17)–Chronic corticosteroid use (> 5 mg prednisone or equivalent for > 3 months)(17)–Excessive thyroid hormone replacement(17)–Heparin(17)–Medroxyprogesterone acetate(17)–Aromatase inhibitors (raloxifene)(17)–Proton pump inhibitors (PPI)(17)

Commonly associated medical conditions(17)–Cardiovascular disease–Diabetes mellitus, type 2 (DM2)–Endocrinopathies: hyperparathyroidism, hyperthyroidism, hypercortisolism–Chronic liver disease (e.g., hemochromatosis)–Hypoestrogenism, which can be associated with menopause, hypogonadism, eating disorders, and elite athletes–Malabsorption syndromes: postgastrectomy, inflammatory bowel disease, celiac disease–Multiple myeloma–Rheumatoid arthritis–COPD–HIV/AIDS–Multiple sclerosis–Osteomalacia–Cancer(27)

The Q Fracture Score uses the following clinical factors to assess fracture risk in men and women 30 to 85 years of age:age, sex, BMI, smoking, alcohol intake, glucocorticoids, asthma, cardiovascular disease, history of falls, chronic liverdisease, rheumatoid arthritis, DM2, and tricyclic antidepressants(15)

The Fracture Risk Assessment (FRAX) algorithm, developed by WHO to evaluate fracture risk, uses the following clinicalrisk factors in men and women 40 to 90 years of age: age, sex, weight, height, previous fracture, parental hip fracture,current smoking, glucocorticoids, rheumatoid arthritis, secondary OP, and alcohol intake (≥ 3units/day)(15)

overall contraindications precautions: Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for fragility fractures and falls
Follow facility protocols for fall prevention or, if inpatient, post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside
It has been recommended that all OP patients, but especially those over 65 years of age, be assessed for fall-risk  factors(2)
Avoid spinal flexion and joint mobilizations/manipulations

Postpone physical activity/exercise therapy and notify physician in case of: chest pain resting systolic BP > 200 mm Hg resting diastolic BP > 110 mm Hg erratic, fluctuating, or inappropriate BP response  severe headache, dizziness, or lightheadedness during exercise prolonged fatigue after exercise
Contact sports should always be avoided
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Stop the exam and notify physician if patient reports the onset of new musculoskeletal symptoms (e.g., pain, swelling, bruising, numbness, paralysis) or severe symptoms associated with exertion (e.g., chest pain, dyspnea, dizziness)
Patients with a history of recurrent falls should have a thorough assessment of fall risk.  (2) (See  Clinical Review ... Falls in Older Adults  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708541)
Assess fear of falling by direct questioning or use of Falls Efficacy Scale(7)

course of treatment.medical management: The general goal of management in OP is to reduce the risk of fracture. Document any specific treatments that have been trialed
course of treatment.medications: Pharmacological interventions specific for OP Calcium 1,200 mg/day and vitamin D 800 IU/day (18) Bisphosphonates (e.g., alendronate [Fosamax], risedronate [Actonel], ibandronate [Boniva], and zoledronic acid) (1) These drugs inhibit the resorption of bone Authors of a meta-analysis  of 9 RCTs (N = 2,464) found that compared to placebo, bisphosphonates (especially zoledronic acid and risedronate) reduce the risk of vertebral and nonvertebral  fractures by increasing BMD in men with OP(43) Osteonecrosis of the jaw has been associated with taking bisphosphonates.There may also be an increased risk of midfemoral fractures in patients taking bisphosphonates for > 5 years Selective estrogen receptor modulators, such as raloxifene (Evista) Teriparatide, a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) Works by stimulating the growth of bone through osteoblastic activation Denosumab Works by inhibiting osteoclast formation Estrogen replacement therapy is not recommended(1) Effectively prevents and treats OP but with increased risk of myocardial infarction, stroke, breast cancer, pulmonary embolus, and DVT Strontium ranelate Seems to inhibit bone resorption and increase bone formation Available only in Europe Calcitonin PTH antagonist that reduces osteoclastic activity, thereby decreasing bone turnover
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests:  OP is diagnosed clinically on the basis of one or more fragility fractures or a T-score  of ≤ 2.5
Measurement of BMD of the lumbar spine and hip by dual-energy  X-ray  absorptiometry (DEXA) is considered the gold standard for the diagnosis of osteoporosis(17)
Screenall women ≥ 65 years with DEXA scan regardless of risk factors
Screen all women > 50 years old with ≤ 10-year  fracture risk (using the FRAX tool) of > 9.3%
Serum biomarkers of bone loss in secondary OP: complete blood count, calcium, phosphate, 25-hydroxyvitamin  D, albumin, alkaline phosphatase, creatinine(20)
X-rays  to assess for fracture (lack sensitivity to diagnose osteoporosis)(17)

Home remedies/complementary therapies:  Document any treatment at home or alternative/complementary therapies (e.g., supplements, acupuncture, yoga, Pilates, tai chi, breathing exercises) that have been tried and whether they were helpful
The combination of creatine supplementation and resistance training may improve BMD and indices of bone biology(28)

Authors of a randomized, crossover trial (N = 24 postmenopausal women) in the United States found that the soy isoflavone supplement genistein had a favorable effect on bone calcium retention, although not as potent as an effect as risedronate(44)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has previously received physical therapy or participated in a supervised exercise program and, if so, describe the regimen and if it was helpful or not

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document aggravating and easing factors and length of time each item is performed before symptoms come on or are eased
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms, any muscle or joint discomfort or pain
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: If present, document number of wakings/night and whether sleeping position is disturbed by OP-related  pain
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate ability to exercise and/ or symptoms that may indicate referral to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, fatigue, saddle anesthesia) -Gastrointestinal symptoms such as difficulty swallowing may be a side effect of taking bisphosphonates(1)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document whether patient uses respiratory support, such as supplemental oxygen or a ventilator. If so, indicate the number of liters of oxygen required and by what means it is being provided Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any history of diseases associated with OP? See  Causes  and Risk Factors , above Document the patient’s typical physical activity level Femoral neck fracture, pathological vertebral fractures, and distal radial fractures are most likely due to OP(22)
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Is patient being treated for any of the following medical conditions anemia, diabetes mellitus, COPD, liver disease, rheumatoid arthritis, multiple myeloma, inflammatory bowel disease, celiac disease, electrolyte abnormalities, hormonal imbalance, metabolic syndrome, seizure disorder, depression, or endocrine disorders?(17) Is the patient a cancer survivor? Many cancer treatments, including some types of chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and hormone therapy, have a negative effect on bone health and can lead to osteoporosis(27) Cancer survivors may be poorly informed about the risk of bone loss due to treatment, especially those who do not fit the normal osteoporosis risk profile(27)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of all prescribed and OTC medications, including nutritional supplements and herbal remedies
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing that have affected functional mobility and QOL. Ask about symptoms related to physical exertion

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Is the patient currently working? If so, describe the job duties. In what recreational activities, physical exercise, or sports does the patient participate? What is the frequency of these physical activities? What hobbies or special interests does the patient have?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does the patient currently use assistive devices or equipment, such as a walker, cane, elevated commode, grab bars, or reachers?
social and occupational history.living environment: With whom does the patient live (family members, caregivers, etc.)? Identify if there are any barriers to patient’s independence in the home. Has the home been assessed for fall safety?Stairs? If so, number of floors in home? Location of bedroom and bathroom? Entrance to the home? Shower vs. bathtub? Modifications within the home may need to be made depending on the patient’s functional mobility status -How does the patient access his or her community (driving, public transportation, walking, etc.)?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate ›Relevant tests and measures:  (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Determine height (and age-related  loss of height), weight, and BMI. Is the patient underweight or overweight? –Low BMI (< 21) is associated with OP(17)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Evaluate the need for any assistive and adaptive devices for ambulation or safety during ADLs. Determine the appropriate fit and instruct in proper use for any of these devices
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic balance reactions using the Berg Balance Scale or functional reach test. Determine if patient’s balance reactions are appropriate for independent use of exercise equipment such as treadmill or elliptical trainer
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Confirm that peripheral pulses are present in all limbs
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess basic ADLs and level of assistance required to safely and independently perform skills such as transfers, bed mobility, grooming, dressing, and toileting –Use the FIM or Timed Up and Go (TUG) test to measure patient’s independence with functional mobility –TUG test can be used as a screening tool to assess fall risk (87% sensitivity and 87% specificity in identifying fallers and non-fallers,  respectively)(9) -Authors of a study in Sweden found that low scores for self-selected  walking speed and TUG test were associated with reduced health-related  QOL (HRQoL) in men and women 60 to 93 years of age with a history of OP-related  fractures(23)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess patient’s gait and note any significant deviations, paying particular attention to stride length, step length/width, cadence, and reciprocal arm swing. Assess self-selected  walking speed over 4 meters,(25)safety of ambulation with Dynamic Gait Index (DGI), gait speed with the 10-meter  walk test, and stairs with the Timed Up and Down Stairs (TUDS) test
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Perform myotomal strength testing for upper and lower extremities using manual muscle testing (MMT) and for grip strength with handheld dynamometry
observation inspection palpation includi: Assess for any physical deformities that may be present that might prevent or restrict participation in the prescribed exercise
Assess trunk in standing position for increased kyphosis, or scoliosis
In addition, assess standing posture for alterations in pelvic tilt, lumbar lordosis, shoulder height/position, calcaneal position, etc.
Palpate soft tissue structures of the extremities and spine for any increased tenderness or pain
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess trunk and bilateral upper and lower extremity ROM and muscle flexibility as indicated, especially the gastrocnemius and soleus, hip flexors, and hamstrings, which can impact functional mobility –Avoid spinal flexionAssess upper and lower extremity deep tendon reflexes Assess bilateral upper and lower extremity dermatomes for any abnormal sensationRefer patient for an occupational therapy evaluation if patient reports or demonstrates difficulty performing self-care  or ADL activities such as grooming, bathing, or dressing
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests –The International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF) Comprehensive Core Set for Osteoporosis can be used to assess a patient’s status in various domains (e.g., sleep, emotions, pain, bladder function, muscle strength and endurance, gait)(10) –Short Form Health Survey (SF-12,  SF-36)  to evaluate HRQoL
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Assess patient’s ability to follow commands and attend to specific tasks. Is patient alert and oriented x 4?

other: Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies
Spinal flexion and joint mobilization/manipulation are contraindicated(11) ›Contraindications/precautions to use of  electrotherapeutic modalities
Electrotherapeutic modalities are not indicated for this condition except when the referring physician prescribes treatment for coexisting musculoskeletal conditions
Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment regarding the use of modalities

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: OP Increased risk for falls and fracturesactivity level, core and extremity strength, spinal and extremity flexibility, balance and safety with ambulation, and ability to perform ADLs independently A therapeutic exercise program may reduce the potential negative effects of OP
assessment plan of care.rule out: Multiple myeloma or other neoplasms, osteomalacia, type I collagen mutations, osteogenesis imperfecta(18)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Physician for management of OP-related  complications; nutritionist for dietary management and advice; occupational therapist for limitations in ADLs; psychiatrist/psychologist for stress/anxiety disorder
other considerations: A paradigm shift in the therapeutic approach to OP places more emphasis on the interaction of bone and muscle, rather than focusing solely on bone(30) –In addition to the mechanical effects of muscle loading on bone function at their anatomic interface, bone-muscle interaction is seen to be an intimate relationship that involves paracrine and endocrine signaling to coordinate their growth and development, and adapt to loading and injury –OP and sarcopenia are closely related conditions characterized by age-related  deterioration of the bone-muscle  unit –Functionally, progressive muscle and bone loss together lead to falls, fractures, deconditioning, and further muscle wasting –This points to a need for the clinical development of novel bone-muscle  therapeutic treatments such as OP site-specific muscle strengthening
treatment summary: Conservative interventions that may help maintain BMD and reduce OP-related  fracture risk include strength training, regular weight-bearing  exercise (e.g., walking), balance training, adequate dietary and/or supplemental calcium, and avoidance of tobacco and excessive alcohol consumption(12,13)

National guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of OP(15,16) –General recommendations -Patient education regarding exercise, dietary supplements, and avoidance of tobacco, alcohol, and caffeine(14) -Programs that target identified impairments in cardiorespiratory endurance, strength, flexibility, posture, balance, and gait -Cardiovascular exercise should involve higher impact exercise (e.g., jogging) if the patient can tolerate it and cleared by physician(14)  -Patients should progress to a program of cardiovascular exercise 3–5 times per week at 75–80% of maximum heart rate, as appropriate and tolerated –Strength training should focus on hip extensors and abductors, knee extensors, ankle dorsi/plantar flexors, and upper extremity strength training that loads through the wrist. Apply to a functional context such as in sit-to-stand and TUG test. Strengthening trunk extensors to reduce thoracic kyphosis, as well as improving posture, may prevent vertebral fractures(14) -Patients should progress to a program of strength training 2–3 times per week at 70–90%  of one repetition maximum (1-RM),  2–3 sets of 8–10 repetitions, as appropriate and tolerated –Include stretching exercises, especially for tight hip flexor and plantar flexor muscles (14) –Include balance retraining exercises, such as functional activities in standing and walking (e.g., reaching in multiple directions and responding to perturbations; walking with turns, over obstacles, on uneven surfaces, and at varied speeds)(14) –Include gait/ambulatory retraining exercises, such as focusing on foot clearance, use of appropriate assistive devices, and safety; distance walking to develop cardiorespiratory endurance(14) –Padded hip protectors may be indicated in high-risk  cases, such as in long-term  care settings

Exercise programs –Exercise and Sports Science Australia (ESSA) published guidelines in 2017 for safe and effective exercise for bone health(46) -Some important concepts: -Although walking is beneficial, in isolation it is not sufficient to optimize bone health -Exercise prescription for the prevention of osteoporosis should begin in childhood -In order for exercise to improve bone health, it must: -be dynamic, not static -induce relatively high bone strains -be applied rapidly -Relatively few loading cycles are required,short bouts followed by rest are more effective, and diversification of loading is necessary -Recommendation is for a minimum of 2 weekly sessions of progressive resistance training (PRT), 4–7 weekly sessions of impact activities, and balance training -An exercise program should take into account an individual’s BMD and functional and clinical risk factors for falls and fracture (e.g., age, history of falls, balance, vision) -Guidelines based on risk of low-trauma  fracture: -Low-risk  individuals (normal BMD and functional status, no clinical risk factors for falls or fracture [e.g., children, adolescents, healthy adults]): the goal is to maximize bone mass and strength.The recommendation includes progressively increasing impact activities including jumps, hops, and multi-directional  weight-bearing activities, recreational sporting activities, high-intensity  PRT, and balance training -Moderate risk individuals (T-score  –1.0 to –2.5,  and some clinical or functional risk factors for fracture): the goal is to preserve or improve bone mass and strength, and improve muscle strength, power, and balance. The recommendation is similar to that for low-risk  individuals, but for individuals approaching a T-score  of –2.5 more moderate impact activities may be appropriate (e.g., running, jumping rope, racket sports). Activities that challenge balance, posture, and mobility should be a greater focus than for low-risk  individuals -High-risk  individuals (T-score  less than –2.5, previous fracture and/or multiple risk factors for fracture): Recommendation is for moderate-impact activities within limits of pain and increasing as tolerated, high-intensity  PRT, and balance, posture, coordination, and mobility exercises. More supervision may be required and spinal flexion must be avoided –Researchers in Iran report that back extensor strengthening can improve QOL in women with OP(45) -In an RCT (N = 183), control group was treated with pharmacology and told to walk 30 minutes, 5 times each week, intervention group also performed back extensor exercises -The outcome measure used was the SF-36.Most  subscales significantly improved in the intervention group over the control group at 6 months –Researchers from Turkey report that clinical Pilates exercises can improve kinesiophobia, pain, functional status, and QOL in women aged 50–75  with OP(47)  -Based on an RCT (N = 40); group 1 received clinical Pilates exercises 3 times per week for 6 weeks; group 2 received no intervention -All outcome measure improvements over the control group were statistically significant –Researchers from Turkey who conducted a 6-month  randomized parallel prospective study found that strengthening exercises were more effective in reducing pain associated with OP and that balance and coordination exercises were more effective in improving static and dynamic balance in women with OP(48) -68 postmenopausal females with osteoporosis were randomized into 3 groups: balance and coordination, strengthening, and aerobic exercise -Groups were compared at 12 and 24 weeks; there were statistically significant improvements in the TUG and Berg Balance Scale at 12 weeks in the balance and coordination group only, and there were statistically significant improvements in night and daytime pain via the V AS at the 12th and 24th weeks in the strengthening group only -There were no falls during the course of the study –Researchers from Germany found that participation in step aerobics resulted in a significant increase in plantar flexor strength in patients ≥ 65 years old with OP compared to controls(49) -Based on a RCT (N = 27); intervention group received supervised modified step aerobic training twice weekly for 6 months and the control group was given a step counter and told to maintain their normal level of physical activity –Researchers in Germany found that sling training exercises were significantly better than traditional physiotherapy in reducing pain and torque forces on the spine in patients with OP(50) -Based on an RCT (N = 44); each group completed a 3-month  program: the control group performed traditional exercises, the intervention group performed similar exercises, but with a sling –A short (4-week)  exercise program for OP can lead to significant changes in self-reported  QOL in women with OP or osteopenia(31) -Based on a study (N = 39) without control subjects conducted in Croatia -All participants completed a 28-day  exercise program -Exercises were 30–45  minutes in duration, with gradual increase in intensity and load -The primary outcome measures were SF-36  and pain (V AS) -Significant improvements in SF-36  and V AS scores were found –Authors of a 2014 meta-analysis  of 7 RCTs (N = 420 adults with low bone mass) found that combining an antiresorptive agent with exercise (n = 205) had additive effects on improving lumbar spine bone mass compared to those (n = 215) who took the antiresorptive agent without exercising(32) –Authors of an RCT conducted in Iran (N = 48 outpatients with hemophilia A and OP) found that resistance training may be effective for improving bone formation(33) –Researchers from the United States who conducted an RCT found that impact and resistance training can be safe and effective for selected older prostate cancer survivors on androgen deprivation therapy, which is associated with significant bone loss(34) –Researchers from Iran report postural training with a weighted kypho-orthosis  (WKO) together with an exercise program may be superior to an exercise program alone for improving balance in women with OP(29) -Based on a nonrandomized controlled trial (N = 31) -Patients in the control group were taught back extensor strengthening exercises to perform at home -Patients in the intervention group performed the same exercise program but in addition were provided with a custom-designed  WKO which they were instructed to wear for one hour per day while ambulating -The patients placed the WKO over the posterior thoracic spine such that a 2 lb pouch was located at the waistline -Functional reach test and TUG test improved significantly in both groups after the 4-week treatment period -Improvements in the WKO group were greater than in the control group . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  Decreased knowledge regarding fracture risk reductionImprove knowledge regarding fracture risk reductionPatient education _ See Treatment summary , above, for detailsN/A Educate family and/or caregivers Decreased BMD Increase BMD Therapeutic exercises _ General strengthening exercises;weight bearing and aerobic exercises _ Please see  Treatment summary  above for detailsProgress each individual as indicatedProvide patient with home program of exercises that includes resistance training and weight-bearing aerobic activity Muscle weakness Increase strength Therapeutic exercises _ General strengthening exercises in either sitting or standing _ _ Focus on exercises that address hip extensors and abductors, knee extensors, and ankle dorsi/plantar flexors; and spinal extension exercises _ Please see  Treatment summary above for detailsProgress resistance with weights or therapeutic bandingInstruct patient in home strengthening program Decreased flexibility/ ROMImprove flexibility/ ROMTherapeutic exercises _ Address specific impairments, especially tightness of hip flexors, hamstrings, and plantar flexorsProgress from static hold to dynamic ROMInstruct patient in home stretching program Limited cardiorespiratory endurance; e.g., 6MWTImprove functional ambulatory enduranceTherapeutic exercises _ Walking program or other aerobic exercises (e.g., elliptical trainer, bike)Progress as tolerated per patient’s abilityUnsupervised walking program, if safe Postural abnormalities Correction of faulty postureFunctional exercises _ Postural retraining exercises; postural educationProgress as tolerated per patient’s abilityContinue exercises at home, as prescribed  Gait and balance impairments that increase fall riskImprove gait and balance performance to reduce risk of fallsGait training _ Address specific deficits and provide assistive devices if needed _ _ Balance training _ Static and dynamic balance exercises, coordination exercises _ Therapeutic exercises Activities aimed at developing muscle strength, balance, and proprioception should be encouraged to prevent falls and fractures(35)Progress difficulty of balance exercises, as toleratedIf safe, prescribe home exercise program incorporating balance activities Restrictions in daily activitiesImprove safety at home and in community _ _ Improve safety in ADLsADLs training _ Functional exercises (e.g., reaching, step up, step down, sit to stand)Progress as tolerated per patient’s abilityIf safe, prescribe home exercise program incorporating functional activities .

reduced fracture risk: BMD–Despite that diagnosis of OP is based on assessment of BMD, there are other determinants of bone strength and fragilitythat can give a more complete measure of bone quality(36)-OP almost always causes increases in bone fragility; however, bone fragility is not always caused solely by OP (i.e., lowBMD)-It has been suggested that OP should be considered as a feature of the disease of skeletal fragility, not as a synonym-As such, assessment of treatment success should not be based merely on changes in BMD
improved lower extremity strength and fl: MMT or weight-lifting  tests for strength, as appropriate

patient education: NIH Osteoporosis and Related Bone Diseases National Resource Center, “Once Is Enough: A Guide to Preventing Future Fractures,” https://www.bones.nih.gov/health-info/bone/osteoporosis/fracture

Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement guideline on diagnosis and treatment of osteoporosis at https://www.icsi.org/ guidelines__more/catalog_guidelines_and_more/catalog_guidelines/catalog_musculoskeletal_guidelines/osteoporosis/

National Osteoporosis Foundation (NOF), https://www.nof.org/ Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
